abstract.p: Silver-plated, palm-sized, snap-shut ashtray noted (Pulse column) (S)

block.p: Stylish ashtrays may not be too prevalent in public places these days: some restaurants furtively supply butter plates to diners who wish to smoke. But for those who long for a chic little place to tap ash, there is a repository: a silver-plated, snap-shut ashtray (left, $16) discreet enough to slip into pocket or purse.

Stylish ashtrays may not be too prevalent in public places these days: some restaurants furtively supply butter plates to diners who wish to smoke. But for those who long for a chic little place to tap ash, there is a repository: a silver-plated, snap-shut ashtray (left, $16) discreet enough to slip into pocket or purse.

And there is a market for it. Nesli Danisman, an owner of Orio-Trio, a tiny home-furnishings shop at 248 Elizabeth Street (Houston Street), said the flying-saucer-shaped ashtray, based on a 1920's Art Deco design, is one of the store's most popular items. Last week, Harvey Weinstein, a co-chairman of Miramax, bought three, she said. Nonsmokers are also being wooed. The same design is being marketed, sans cigarette rest, as a ''travel candleholder'' in the new Pottery Barn catalogue -- for those who have a lesser-known compulsion to light up.
